deIdi2b2.TEXT:
Record date: 2070-10-24
EDVISIT^53954143^Rutledge, Xavier^10/24/70^OCASIO, WANDA
This patient was seen by myself and Dr. Pappas on 10/24/2070. I
confirm that I interviewed and examined the patient, reviewed the
resident's documentation and discussed plan of care with the
patient.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 61-year-old gentleman with
a history of cadaveric renal transplant 11 years ago with a
history of DVT, on Coumadin, diabetes, chronic right lower
extremity edema, who comes in with dysuria and chills. He had no
urinary output since last night. He says his fevers started this
morning above 101. He went to his PCP who sent him here. He
denies any nausea or vomiting. He has mild lower suprapubic
abdominal pain and some mild flank pain. He has had some urinary
frequency.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Hypertension, diabetes, gout,
hypercholesterolemia, end-stage renal disease, status post
transplant, anemia, BPH, and DVT.
MEDICATIONS: Please refer to the EDUCARE-FARGO list in the chart.
ALLERGIES: He has allergies to codeine.
SOCIAL HISTORY: He is not a smoker, drinker, or drug user.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: As noted in the HPI, otherwise negative.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: He is an ill-appearing gentleman with
rigors. Vital signs are as noted. Head, eyes, ears, nose, and
throat are unremarkable. Neck is supple. He does have dry
mucous membranes. Chest is clear to auscultation. Heart is
slightly tachycardic. Abdomen has some suprapubic fullness and
tenderness but otherwise is benign. His rectal exam is
heme-positive. There is no prostate tenderness. His skin is
warm and flushed. He has got toe amputations. Extremities are
otherwise unremarkable. Neuro exam is nonfocal.
LABORATORY DATA: He has got a white count of 14, hematocrit of
35, and platelet count 139,000. SMA-7 shows bicarbonate of 15
with an anion gap of 15, and a creatinine of 4.7 which is up from
his baseline. LFTs are otherwise unremarkable. A chest x-ray
was unremarkable.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: He did get a Foley catheter with
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
obstruction. He was given levofloxacin and vancomycin. He was
also given Tylenol. He got some IV fluids. He had an INR of 2.6
which was about baseline. The plan was to admit him to the
hospital. Transplant was subsequently called.
DIAGNOSIS: Pyelonephritis.
______________________________
OCASIO, WANDA M.D.
D: 10/26/70
T: 10/26/70
Dictated By: OCASIO, WANDA
